1.name: Saúl Segura
1.about: Even in Barcelona’s youth system, Segura stood out with his rare combination of size, skill, and scoring touch. Once considered a potential number one pick, his position isn’t guaranteed, but elite physical tools, instincts, and versatility keep him firmly in contention at the top.

2.name: Joshua Boston
2.about: A top-five recruit and projected number two overall pick, Boston enters Tennessee with All-NBA talent potential. Explosive first step, elite vertical, and transition dominance make him nearly unguardable, with scouts seeing superstar upside written across his game and expecting him to make an immediate impact.

3.name: Isaiah Bailey
3.about: Arriving at Duke as one of the top freshmen, Bailey is known as a premier shot-maker in his class. His isolation scoring, excellent three-point shooting, and offensive creativity make him a dangerous weapon, projecting as an instant-impact scorer at the next level.

4.name: Adam Riley
4.about: The nation’s top recruit, Riley joins Gonzaga as a 7’0” big with a 7’5” wingspan. A shot-obliterating rim presence and defensive anchor, he’s expected to dominate defensively, while scouts continue evaluating how his offensive game will develop to match his elite physical tools.

5.name: Nicola Mancini
5.about: Recruited from Italy to Illinois, Mancini is projected as a top-five pick with a rare blend of size, two-way ability, and guard skills. At 6’6”, he showcases lockdown defensive instincts and smooth mid-range scoring, standing out as one of the most complete freshman guards nationally.

6.name: Jaylen Summers
6.about: The top-ranked guard in his class, Summers begins at UCLA as a projected top-10 pick. Rare burst, vertical pop, and devastating rim attacks in transition and half court make him dangerous, while scouts watch closely to see if his jumper can unlock true superstar upside.

7.name: Kam Howland Jr
7.about: Howland enters Arizona as one of the nation’s purest shooters, projecting as a floor-spacing weapon from day one. Compact release, deep range, and quick-twitch movement allow him to create openings off the ball, keeping defenders honest and making him an immediate offensive threat.

8.name: Amanté Roberts
8.about: Roberts joins UCLA as one of two projected top-10 picks, bringing pro-ready size and strength to the frontcourt. At 6’9”, 240 pounds with a 7’4” wingspan, he combines mid-post touch and physicality, projecting as a dominant interior presence at the next level.

9.name: Jack Rice
9.about: Entering his sophomore season at BYU, Rice is projected as a top-10 pick and recognized as one of the nation’s most efficient spot-up shooters. At 6’7”, he averaged 1.15 points per possession on spot-ups as a freshman, showcasing NBA-ready floor spacing and secondary scoring.

10.name: Isaiah Nesbitt
10.about: A 5-star recruit and projected top-10 pick, Nesbitt joins Kentucky as a polished 6’8” scoring wing. Advanced mid-range game, fluid touch, and length make him a matchup problem, with scouts seeing him as one of the most NBA-ready freshmen in the class.

11.name: Xavion Booker
11.about: A top-10 recruit and five-star talent, Booker enters USC with a legendary high school résumé. Left-handed scoring, creative shot-making, and pedigree give him lottery buzz, though questions about efficiency and defensive consistency leave scouts monitoring how he adjusts at the next level.

12.name: Mohamed Jacobs
12.about: Jacobs joins Texas as a lightning-quick playmaker and natural table setter. Elite speed in transition and ability to create for teammates give him intrigue, though concerns about strength, finishing, and shooting limit early projections and leave questions about his long-term upside.

13.name: Trey James
13.about: Trey James arrives at UNC as a five-star freshman with a reputation for crafty scoring and steady ball-handling. While not considered a surefire star, his size, creativity, and polished offense project him as a late lottery pick with room to grow.

14.name: Mathys Moreau
14.about: Projected in the mid-first round, Cholet’s Mathys Moreau blends size, mobility, and a reliable shooting stroke. This modern stretch-five prospect displays developmental upside, capable of contributing as a floor-spacing big while refining defensive positioning and overall NBA readiness.

15.name: Quaylen Douglas
15.about: Douglas enters Michigan as an explosive but smaller guard, projected in the late first round. Quickness, perimeter shooting, and agility give him intrigue, though size limitations may cap upside, making him an exciting but potentially risky freshman prospect for NBA scouts.

16.name: Mark Bolton
16.about: Bolton opens the season projected in the mid-first round as a strong big man with an NBA-ready frame. Physical tools, rebounding instincts, and interior touch give him early lottery buzz, projecting as a dominant post presence who can thrive immediately at the next level.

17.name: Cam Lee
17.about: Projected at 17, Lee entered the season with age-related concerns but still viewed as a high-usage guard with microwave scoring ability. Despite limited experience, his quick scoring, offensive creativity, and potential for improvement make him a notable prospect in the freshman class.

18.name: Andrew Bolden Jr.
18.about: A physical junior wing at Gonzaga, Bolden projects as a top-20 pick thanks to defensive motor and frame. Ability to guard multiple positions and impact on both ends of the floor earns him early buzz as a versatile two-way talent entering the NBA radar.

19.name: Justinas Jakčinskas
19.about: Joining Arkansas under Coach Calipari, Jakčinskas brings length and energy to the frontcourt. As a 5-star recruit, he projects as a late first-round pick, showing shot-blocking ability, mobility, and potential to develop into a two-way contributor with NBA upside.

20.name: Terrence James
20.about: The second of two top-10 freshmen for Tennessee, James is a premier 3&D prospect. In high school, he showcased length, energy, perimeter shooting, and defensive instincts, thriving as a floor-spacing weapon while creation remains limited, leaving scouts watching his adaptation to the college game.

21.name: Dustin Anderson
21.about: Anderson enters Oklahoma with a huge fan following after a highlight-filled high school career. Athleticism, mid-range scoring, and leaping ability make him exciting, though outside shooting and decision-making remain concerns, leaving scouts evaluating how he will transition to the college level.

22.name: Sincere Johnston
22.about: Johnston returned to Alabama as a sophomore to improve his draft stock after flashes as a crafty scorer. Polished isolation skills, footwork, and mid-post creativity allow him to generate buckets, though efficiency, defensive consistency, and motor continue to be areas for evaluation.

23.name: Ismaël Aït Salah
23.about: Aït Salah joins Perth as a versatile forward with length and defensive instincts. Athletic slashing, rim protection, and versatility project him as one of the top international prospects, though shooting consistency and offensive polish remain questions scouts will monitor closely.

24.name: Miles Gibson
24.about: Gibson arrives at Ohio State as a physically imposing post big, known for strength and rebounding. He thrives against smaller opponents inside, though mobility, perimeter defense, and shooting consistency raise questions about his early NBA impact and long-term upside.

25.name: Darius Hall
25.about: Hall, the youngest player in college basketball, will still be 18 at the NBA season’s start. A powerful Auburn freshman, he flashes athletic rim protection and lob-threat ability, though raw shooting and decision-making make him a developmental prospect with intriguing upside.

26.name: Tylen Morgan
26.about: Morgan enters Texas as a mobile big with rim-running instincts and rebounding prowess. Excelling in transition and finishing lobs, he remains raw offensively. Limited shooting and defensive discipline keep him a developmental project, projecting as a long-term NBA prospect with upside potential.

27.name: Riley Jamison
27.about: Jamison, a five-star recruit for Arizona, enters projected in the back half of the second round. Skilled shot creation, deep range, and passing vision make him intriguing, though size and defensive limitations leave scouts questioning how high his NBA ceiling may rise.

28.name: Taji Anikulapo-Kuti
28.about: Anikulapo-Kuti arrives at Kentucky as a versatile forward with elite length and defensive tools. A physical ball hawk who disrupts passing lanes and finishes through contact, his shooting and offensive polish remain question marks as he begins his collegiate career.

29.name: Tim McDuffie
29.about: McDuffie enters North Carolina as a mobile big with rim-running ability and natural shot-blocking instincts. Athleticism and length make him a transition threat, but strength and skill refinement are needed before he can make a serious NBA impact at the next level.

30.name: Mark Smiley
30.about: Iowa’s Smiley enters the draft radar as a proven shooter with a reliable floor presence. Three-point accuracy and isolation scoring make him dependable offensively, though average athleticism and defensive limitations temper long-term upside, projecting him as a reliable, floor-spacing contributor at the next level.
